instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00923: What is 820-00923? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good” and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.RTC_RESET_L: What is RTC_RESET_L? RTC_RESET_L is a reset signal that is present when the signal is low, the _L means it is asserted when the voltage is low. The RESET signal will keep the PCH from turning on or booting up the machine. .
definitions.PCH_SRTCRST_L: What is PCH_SRTCRST_L? PCH_SRTCRST_L is a reset signal present for the RTC circuit that asserts when it is low in voltage, that is what _L means..
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PCH_INTRUDER_L: What is PCH_INTRUDER_L? PCH_INTRUDER_L is a signal that tells the machine the case has been opened by an intruder when it is low, the _L means it is present when it is low. This signal should always be high in a Macbook since it doesn’t use intrusion detection. .
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.PPVBAT_G3H_CONN: What is PPVBAT_G3H_CONN? This is the where the battery’s power rail connects to the motherboard. .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a not turning on.
threads.message:
Board with water damage. 

There was a short on PPBUS. 

Changed <CHIP>U7900</CHIP> and U800 ( were bad)


Now getting: 

PPBUS,  <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>/SUS. Checked big coils and no pulse. On charger i get 20V and stack at 0.04 AMPS.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a not turning on.
threads.message: Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a not turning on.
threads.message:
Sorry for delay. Customer asked me to stop repairing ( financial issues :D). No we retake it. 


Yes when i triger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>  <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> drops from 3.3 to 0.3V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a not turning on.
threads.message: Check if <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL> signals pulse at same time.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a not turning on.
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> - missing and shorted but <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL>- 3.3V. May i inject voltage?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a not turning on.
threads.message:
Exact ohm resistance to ground at <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>?
Allow 10-15s after power is removed...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a not turning on.
threads.message: Sorry, i was wrong.  <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>  is not shorted and has 100Kohms to ground. but 0V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a not turning on.
threads.message:
"Yes when i triger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>  <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> drops from 3.3 to 0.3V"
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> pulse at same time???

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a not turning on.
threads.message: No, Both stay 0.0V. Only <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> drops down

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a not turning on.
threads.message:
Then you have a PCH issue.
Check PCH's RTC and <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> signals.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a not turning on.
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>  - 3.4V

RTC of PCH u mean this?:


<SIGNAL>RTC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> - 2.7V
<SIGNAL>PCH_SRTCRST_L</SIGNAL> - 2.7V


P.S. Seems that there was overload on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_CPU</SIGNAL> because all points of componentes on that line seems be a bit other color ( like burnt), but i get 13V on that line.

Also if it can help: connecting charger i get 20V and about 0.10-0.11 Amps.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a not turning on.
threads.message:
Still missing <SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL> signal.
If good, then possibly bad PCH/CPU; check if <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> goes high.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a not turning on.
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL>  - 2.5V
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>   - 3.3V


P.S. Also <SIGNAL>PPVBAT_G3H_CONN</SIGNAL> is a bit burnt but i get 12.5V. May be it damaged <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>? <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> on this models comes with firmware, right? So i cannot just take it from any board, it must be same board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a not turning on.
threads.message:
<CHIP>U7000</CHIP> is good, as you get correct <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.

Looks like bad PCH...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a not turning on.
threads.message:
Nothing more to check than?

if not, do u knowanhthing about dara recovery machine for this models? I saw there was a device that recover data from faulty logic board

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a not turning on.
threads.message:
The boards with Lifeboat connector, offer the option to recover SSD data with special tool.
Only if there is not a problem with SSD power rails.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a not turning on.
threads.message:
Could u explain me
More please? Where i can get that tool?
